techs.name: 3D displays
techs.description: Displays that appear to have depth.

techs.name: 4D Printing
techs.description: The manufacture of end-use products using additive manufacturing techniques and materials that are able to change and mutate over time when exposed to water, temperature changes and/or air to self assemble.

techs.name: 4K
techs.description: An emerging standard for resolution in digital film and computer graphics with approximately four times of a full HD image.

techs.name: 5G
techs.description: Pervasive networks providing ubiquitous computing. The user can simultaneously be connected to several wireless access technologies and seamlessly move between them.

techs.name: Advanced Concrete
techs.description: A new water-repellant concrete impregnated with tiny superstrong fibers promises to leave roads and bridges free of major cracks for up to 120 years.

techs.name: Aerial Wireless Network
techs.description: Use drones or balloon-based designed to partly solve the problem of limited internet access across the globe.

techs.name: Aerogel
techs.description: A synthetic porous ultralight material derived from a gel, in which the liquid component of the gel has been replaced with a gas. Potential applications include improved thermal insulation, chemical absorber for cleaning up spills, electrochemical supercapacitors and shock absorption.

techs.name: Agricultural Drones
techs.description: Relatively cheap drones with advanced sensors and imaging capabilities are giving farmers new ways to increase yields and reduce crop damage.

techs.name: Agricultural robots
techs.description: Also known as agbots, these are used to automate agricultural processes, such as harvesting, fruit picking, ploughing, soil mainte- nance, weeding, planting, irrigation, etc

techs.name: Air & soil sensors
techs.description: Fundamental additions to the automated farm, these sensors would enable a real time understanding of current farm, forest or body of water conditions.

techs.name: Annotated-reality glasses
techs.description: Like Google Glass, these technologies add a layer of information on top of reality without replacing the underlying objects. Not to be confused with Agumented Reality, which is able to simulate virtual objects for the user.

techs.name: Anti-aging drugs
techs.description: Refers to attempts to slow down or reverse the processes of aging to extend both the maximum and average lifespan. Is also known as antiaging medicine or life extension.

techs.name: Artificial organs
techs.description: Man-made device that is implanted or integrated into a human to replace a natural organ.

techs.name: Artificial photosynthesis
techs.description: A renewable, carbon-neutral source of fuel, producing either hydrogen, or carbohydrates. This sets it apart from the other popular renewable energy sources, which produce electricity directly, with no fuel intermediate.

techs.name: Artificial retinas
techs.description: Give the blind the barest sense of what’s visible, but potentially can allow blind patients to see over human average capabilities.

techs.name: Attention economies
techs.description: When attention is paid, spent, given, taken – or transacted – it becomes influence, which then develops as capital.

techs.name: Augmented reality
techs.description: A live view of real-world environment whose elements are augmented by computer-generated sensory input such as sound, video, metadata or graphics.

techs.name: Autonomous cars
techs.description: Vehicles capable of sensing its environment and navigating on their own.

techs.name: Big data intelligence
techs.description: Databases that proactively make decisions and meta-decisions about how to process, capture and store data by analysing it's content.

techs.name: Big Data Skin Patches
techs.description: Track vital and biometric signs to administer medication just when its needed.

techs.name: Biohacking
techs.description: A techno-progressive cultural and intellectual movement which advocates for open access to genetic information and defends the potential of truly democratic technological development. Biohacking can also refer to managing one's own biology using a combination of medical, nutritional and electronic techniques. This may include the use of nootropics and/or cybernetic devices for recording biometric data.

techs.name: Biologically extended senses
techs.description: The idea is based on the principle that the brain evolved to handle one construction of reality, yet now can overlay multiple local and remote experiences simultaneously, creating new cognitive perceptions. Biological senses can be enhanced and produced artificially, which adapt and transform to address different kinds of stimuli for specific purposes.

techs.name: Biomaterials
techs.description: Derived either from nature or synthesized in the laboratory, biomaterials can be used to enhance or replace natural functions in the body.

techs.name: Biometric sensors
techs.description: The use of biometrics to telecommunications and telecommunications for remote biometric sensing. Potential applications include monitoring blood levels, infections and efficacy of vaccine.

startups.name: Quape
startups.description: The assignment of physical and online tasks traditionally performed by human agents to an autonomous software agent.

startups.name: Toptags
startups.description: Create human tissue for a patient with their own cells that could be transplanted.

startups.description: A live view of real-world environment whose elements are augmented by computer-generated sensory input such as sound, video, metadata or graphics.

startups.name: Twitterbridge

startups.name: Kaymba
startups.description: Interfaces used for assisting, augmenting, or repairing human cognitive or sensory-motor functions and communicate thoughts and intentions to the internet.

startups.name: Quaboo

startups.name: GigaXS
startups.description: Microscopic technological structures that extract biometric information from an organism to analyze its performance and improve specific biological functions with assisted feedback. In terms of personal biometry, bionic implants represent great tools to empower preventive medicine and develop customized solutions for specific organisms and diseases.

startups.name: Leelane
startups.description: A techno-progressive cultural and intellectual movement which advocates for open access to genetic information and defends the potential of truly democratic technological development. Biohacking can also refer to managing one's own biology using a combination of medical, nutritional and electronic techniques. This may include the use of nootropics and/or cybernetic devices for recording biometric data.

startups.name: Buzzblab
startups.description: A new map, a decade in the works, shows structures of the brain in far greater detail than ever before, providing neuroscientists with a guide to its immense complexity.
